## Vectors

Recall from last lesson, we assign single values inside a variable like this:

```{r recap, exercise=TRUE}
my_age <- 16
```

\
If we want store multiple objects, we assign them to an object called a **vector**.

To do this in R, we put the values in this `c()` function. The `c()` function is used to **c**ombine values.

```{r combine, exercise = TRUE}
ages <- c(50,55,60,65)
ages
```

```{r combine2_setup, include= FALSE}
ages <- c(50,55,60,65)
```

\

Here's a more detailed look into each part of the code to make a vector:

<center>
<img src="https://private-user-images.githubusercontent.com/36866649/471266768-cbafe810-204e-46c2-a886-afebd320972d.png?jwt=eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..1Ye6AEa_KOlVEIBGSEKMTF3HpPutt1kq2C7EcE08Y80" width = 850>
</center>

<small>Image credit: [Emma Rand](https://buzzrbeeline.blog/tag/rstats/)

---



\
We can use the `c()` function to add more values is an existing vector.
```{r combine2, exercise = TRUE, exercise.setup="combine2_setup"}
more_ages <- c(ages, 70)
more_ages
```


## Indexing
Each element in a vector has an associated **index**, or **position**, that we can use as a reference. The **index** tells us the **position** of the element in the vector. 

Take the following vector as an example:
```{r organs, exercise=TRUE}
organs <- c("lungs", "heart", "kidney", "brain", "stomach", "liver", "spleen")

```

```{r organs_setup, include=FALSE}
organs <- c("lungs", "heart", "kidney", "brain", "stomach", "liver", "spleen")

```

\
If we want to access the 3rd value in `organs`, we use square brackets `[]` with the vector like this: `organs[3]`. 
```{r organs3, exercise=TRUE, exercise.setup="organs_setup"}
organs[3]

```


\
In the code chunk below, extract the 6th item in `organs`. 
```{r organs6, exercise = TRUE, exercise.setup="organs_setup"}

```

::: {#organs6-hint}
Use square brackets `[]` with the number 6 inside: `organs[6]`
:::

```{r organs6-solution}
organs[6]
```

```{r organs6-check}
grade_code(
  correct = "Excellent! You successfully extracted the 6th element from the organs vector. The liver is at position 6.",
  incorrect = "Not quite. Remember to use square brackets with the index number inside: organs[6]"
)
```

## Subsetting

Recall that the `organs` vector is:
```{r}
organs <- c("lungs", "heart", "kidney", "brain", "stomach", "liver", "spleen")

```

\

We can also use indexing to extract multiple values from the vector. This is called **subsetting** a vector.

To get the first **through** third elements use the `:` symbol like this: `organs[c(1:3)]`. 
```{r subset1, exercise= TRUE, exercise.setup="organs_setup"}

```


\
To get the **only first and third**, we need to first make a vector with 1 and 3 or `c(1,3)` and then put the vector in square brackets `[]`. 


```{r subset3, exercise= TRUE, exercise.setup="organs_setup"}
index <- c(1,3)
organs[index]

```

```{r subset3-hint}
index <- c(1,3)
organs[index]

```

\
Alternatively, it can be written in one line:
```{r subset4, exercise=TRUE, exercise.setup="organs_setup"}
organs[c(1,3)]

```


## Practice
Recall that the `organs` vector is:
```{r}
organs <- c("lungs", "heart", "kidney", "brain", "stomach", "liver", "spleen")

```

\
1. Extract the third through the sixth values in the `organs` vector. 
```{r subset5, exercise=TRUE, exercise.setup="organs_setup"}


```

::: {#subset5-hint}
Use the colon `:` to get a range of values: `organs[3:6]`
:::

```{r subset5-solution}
organs[3:6]
```

```{r subset5-check}

  correct = "Perfect! You extracted elements 3 through 6: kidney, brain, stomach, and liver.",
  incorrect = "Try using the colon operator to get a range: organs[3:6]"
)
```

\
1. Extract the second **and** seventh values in the `organs` vector.
```{r subset6, exercise=TRUE, exercise.setup="organs_setup"}


```

::: {#subset6-hint}
Use `c()` to combine specific index numbers: `organs[c(2,7)]`
:::

```{r subset6-solution}
organs[c(2,7)]
```

```{r subset6-check}
grade_code(
  correct = "Great work! You successfully extracted the 2nd and 7th elements: heart and spleen.",
  incorrect = "Remember to use c() to combine the index numbers: organs[c(2,7)]"
)
```

\
1. Extract the third through the sixth, the first, and the seventh value in the `organs` vector.
```{r subset7, exercise=TRUE, exercise.setup="organs_setup"}


```

::: {#subset7-hint}
Combine ranges and individual indices using `c()`: `organs[c(3:6, 1, 7)]`
:::

```{r subset7-solution}

```

```{r subset7-check}
grade_code(
  correct = "Excellent! You combined both ranges (3:6) and individual indices (1, 7) to extract multiple elements.",
  incorrect = "Try combining ranges and individual numbers: organs[c(3:6, 1, 7)]"
)
```

## Exercise 1 {data-progressive="TRUE"}

Let's get started with the in-class exercises. This exercise set will cover the Vectors material. 

\
Vectors are objects where we can store multiple values! They can hold any data type (characters, numerics, integers, logicals), but all the values in a vector have to be the same data type.

\
Another way to think about vectors are lists like `(10,12,45)` or `("red", "orange", "pink")`.

### Q1 of 7
Let's try it out. To make a vector you use the `c()` function. Assign the variable `vector_1` a vector of `(1,2,3)`. 

```{r ex1, exercise=TRUE}


```

::: {#ex1-hint}
The assignment operator is `<-` or `=`.
:::

```{r ex1-solution}
# with <- operator ----
vector_1 <- c(1,2,3)

# with = operator ----
vector_1 = c(1,2,3)
```

```{r ex1-check}
grade_code(
  correct = "Perfect! You've created your first vector with three numeric values. The `c()` function combines values into a vector.",
  incorrect = "Make sure to use the `c()` function to combine the values and assign them to `vector_1`."
)
```


### Q2 of 7

You can add values to the end of an existing vector by entering `c(vector, new_value)`.

\
Add `4` to the end of `vector_1`.
```{r ex2_setup, include = FALSE}
vector_1 = c(1,2,3)
```

::: {#ex2-hint}
The argument for the new value goes after the argument for the vector.
:::

```{r ex2, exercise=TRUE, exercise.setup="ex2_setup"}


```


```{r ex2-solution}
c(vector_1, 4)

```

```{r ex2-check}
grade_code(
  correct = "Great! You successfully added 4 to the end of vector_1. Notice how the new vector now contains (1,2,3,4).",
  incorrect = "Remember to put the existing vector first, then the new value: `c(vector_1, 4)`"
)
```

### Q3 of 7
Now that we are able to add `4` to the end of `vector_1`, let's reassign `vector_1` with the updated vector `c(vector_1, 4)`. 
```{r ex3, exercise=TRUE, exercise.setup="ex2_setup"}


```

::: {#ex3-hint}
Assigned `vector_1` with the vector you created in Q2. 
:::


```{r ex3-solution}
# with <- operator ----
vector_1 <- c(vector_1, 4)

# with = operator ----
vector_1 = c(vector_1, 4)
```

```{r ex3-check}
grade_code(
  correct = "Excellent! You've updated vector_1 to permanently include the value 4. Now vector_1 contains (1,2,3,4).",
  incorrect = "Use the assignment operator to update vector_1: vector_1 <- c(vector_1, 4)"
)
```


### Q4 of 7

Similarly, you can add values to the beginning of vectors by typing `c(new value, vector)`.

\
Add `0` to the beginning of `vector_1`. 

```{r ex4_setup, include = FALSE}
vector_1 = c(1,2,3,4)
```

::: {#ex4-hint}
The argument for the value goes before the argument for the vector.
:::

```{r ex4, exercise=TRUE, exercise.setup="ex4_setup"}


```


```{r ex4-solution}
c(0, vector_1)

```

```{r ex4-check}
grade_code(
  correct = "Perfect! You added 0 to the beginning of the vector. Notice how the order matters - the new value comes first.",
  incorrect = "Put the new value first, then the existing vector: c(0, vector_1)"
)
```


### Q5 of 7

Now that we are able to add `0` to the beginning of `vector_1`, let's reassign `vector_1` with the updated vector (`c(0, vector_1)`). 

```{r ex5_setup, include = FALSE}
vector_1 = c(1,2,3,4)
```

::: {#ex5-hint}
Assigned `vector_1` with the vector you created in Q4. 
:::

```{r ex5, exercise=TRUE, exercise.setup="ex5_setup"}


```


```{r ex5-solution}
# with <- operator ----
vector_1 <- c(0, vector_1)

# with = operator ----
vector_1 = c(0, vector_1)
```

```{r ex5-check}
grade_code(
  correct = "Great work! You've successfully updated vector_1 to start with 0. Your vector now contains (0,1,2,3,4).",
  incorrect = "Remember to reassign vector_1 with the new vector: vector_1 <- c(0, vector_1)"
)
```




### Q6 of 7

Add `5` to the BEGINNING of `vector_1` and reassign it to `vector_1`. 
```{r ex6_setup, include = FALSE}
vector_1 = c(0,1,2,3,4)
```

::: {#ex6-hint}
Put the new value 5 first, then the existing vector, and assign it back to `vector_1`.
:::

```{r ex6, exercise=TRUE, exercise.setup="ex6_setup"}


```


```{r ex6-solution}
# with <- operator ----
vector_1 <- c(5, vector_1)

# with = operator ----
vector_1 = c(5, vector_1)
```

```{r ex6-check}
grade_code(
  correct = "Excellent! You've added 5 to the beginning and reassigned the vector. Your final vector is (5,0,1,2,3,4).",
  incorrect = "Remember to put 5 first and reassign to vector_1: vector_1 <- c(5, vector_1)"
)
```

### Q7 of 7

```{r ex7, echo=FALSE}
question_checkbox('What is the final order of values in `vector_1`?',
  answer("5, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4", correct = TRUE),
  answer("0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5"),
  answer("1, 2, 3, 4, 5 "),
  answer("0, 1, 2, 3, 4"),
  try_again = "Not exactly. Print out the variable `vector_1` in the previous code chunk!",
  allow_retry = TRUE,
  random_answer_order = TRUE,
  correct = "Great work! Looks like you can make vectors and add values to them!"
  )
```

## Exercise 2 {data-progressive="TRUE"}

### Q1 of 9

Each element in a vector has an associated index that can be used as a reference. 
\

<center><img src="https://blog.ed.ted.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/tumblr_inline_naitcpvDNp1sndsvm.gif" height=200></center>

\
Make a new vector called `organs` and assign these values `"lung"`, `"heart"`, `"kidney"`, `"brain"`, `"skin"`, `"liver"`.

```{r ex2_1, exercise=TRUE}


```

::: {#ex2_1-hint}
`c()` is the function for making new vectors. 
:::


```{r ex2_1-solution}
# with <- operator ----
organs <- c("lung", "heart", "kidney", "brain", "skin", "liver")

# with = operator ----
organs = c("lung", "heart", "kidney", "brain", "skin", "liver")
```

```{r ex2_1-check}
grade_code(
  correct = "Perfect! You've created a character vector with six organ names. Notice how all values are in quotes since they're text.",
  incorrect = "Make sure to use `c()` and put each organ name in quotes: organs <- c(\"lung\", \"heart\", \"kidney\", \"brain\", \"skin\", \"liver\")"
)
```

### Q2 of 9
Great! Now we have an `organs` vector that looks like this:
```{r}
organs <- c("lung", "heart", "kidney", "brain", "skin", "liver")
```

We can use the square brackets `[]` to extract values at a specific position (index) of a vector.

\
In R indexes start at 1, meaning the first value in a vector is in position 1.

\
Extract the value at index 1 of `organs`.
```{r ex2_2_setup, include=FALSE}
organs <- c("lung", "heart", "kidney", "brain", "skin", "liver")


```

::: {#ex2_2-hint}
Put the square brackets `[]` after the vector name followed by the position of the item you want.
:::

```{r ex2_2, exercise=TRUE, exercise.setup="ex2_2_setup"}


```


```{r ex2_2-solution}
organs[1]

```

```{r ex2_2-check}
grade_code(
  correct = "Excellent! You extracted the first element 'lung' from the organs vector. Remember, R uses 1-based indexing.",
  incorrect = "Use square brackets with the index number: organs[1]"
)
```


### Q3 of 9
```{r}
organs <- c("lung", "heart", "kidney", "brain", "skin", "liver")
```

You can use a negative number to exclude a value in that position. 

\
Try excluding the value at index 2 of the vector `organs`. 

```{r ex2_3, exercise=TRUE, exercise.setup="ex2_2_setup"}


```

::: {#ex2_3-hint}
Put the square brackets `[]` after the vector name followed by the position of the item you want.
:::

```{r ex2_3-solution}
organs[-2]

```

```{r ex2_3-check}
grade_code(
  correct = "Great! You excluded 'heart' (position 2) and got all other organs. Negative indexing is useful for removing specific elements.",
  incorrect = "Use a negative sign before the index number: organs[-2]"
)
```


### Q4 of 9

You can use accessors to extract multiple values from a vector, this is called **subsetting.**

\
Here is an example: `vector[c(index1,index2)]` will let you get the values at `index1` and `index2`.

\
Let's extract the **first and fifth** values in our `organs` vectors (shown below):
```{r}
organs <- c("lung", "heart", "kidney", "brain", "skin", "liver")
```


::: {#ex2_4-hint}
Enter the vector name, followed by the index numbers you want to extract in a seperate vector.
:::


```{r ex2_4, exercise=TRUE, exercise.setup="ex2_2_setup"}


```


```{r ex2_4-solution}
organs[c(1,5)]


```

```{r ex2_4-check}
grade_code(
  correct = "Perfect! You extracted 'lung' and 'skin' (positions 1 and 5). This is how you select non-consecutive elements.",
  incorrect = "Use c() to combine the index numbers: organs[c(1,5)]"
)
```


### Q5 of 9

If you wanted to get values from `index1` through `index2`, you use the colon `:` like this `vector[c(index1:index2)]` 

\
Extract the **first through fifth** values in the `organs` vectors (shown below):
```{r}
organs <- c("lung", "heart", "kidney", "brain", "skin", "liver")
```


```{r ex2_5, exercise=TRUE, exercise.setup="ex2_2_setup"}


```

::: {#ex2_5-hint}
Use the colon operator to get a range: `organs[1:5]` or `organs[c(1:5)]`
:::

```{r ex2_5-solution}
# with c() ----
organs[c(1:5)]

# without c() ----
organs[1:5]
```

```{r ex2_5-check}
grade_code(
  correct = "Excellent! You extracted the first five organs using the colon operator. This gives you a continuous range of elements.",
  incorrect = "Use the colon operator for ranges: organs[1:5]"
)
```


### Q6 of 9

Extract the second AND third items in `organs`.
```{r}
organs <- c("lung", "heart", "kidney", "brain", "skin", "liver")
```


```{r ex2_6, exercise=TRUE, exercise.setup="ex2_2_setup"}


```

::: {#ex2_6-hint}
Do you want index2 AND index3 or index2 THROUGH index3?
:::

```{r ex2_6-solution}
# c() solution ----
organs[c(2,3)]

# c() colon solution ----
organs[c(2:3)]

# colon solution ----
organs[2:3]
```

```{r ex2_6-check}
grade_code(
  correct = "Great work! You extracted 'heart' and 'kidney'. Since positions 2 and 3 are consecutive, both c(2,3) and 2:3 work equally well.",
  incorrect = "Use either organs[c(2,3)] or organs[2:3] to get consecutive elements"
)
```

### Q1 

Let's create a new vector called `organs` that contains the values `"lung"`, `"prostate"`, `"breast"`. 


```{r ex4_1, exercise=TRUE}


```

Use the c() function and put each organ name in quotes.
:::

### Q3

There is a function (we will learn more about these next lesson) that we can use to check what data type a variable is.

\
`class()` is a function that tells you the data type of the inputted variable. You can use the function by typing `class()` and inserting the variable into the `()`.

\
Let's find the data type of `organs` using the function `class()`. 
```{r ex4_3_setup, include=FALSE}
organs <- c("lung", "prostate", "breast")
```

```{r ex4_3, exercise=TRUE, exercise.setup="ex4_3_setup"}


```

::: {#ex4_3-hint}
Type `class(organs)`.
:::

```{r ex4_3-solution}
class(organs)
```

```{r ex4_3-check}
grade_code(
  correct = "Excellent! The class() function shows that organs is a 'character' vector. This function is very useful for checking data types.",
  incorrect = "Put the variable name inside the parentheses: class(organs)"
)
```


### Q4

R tends to handle interpreting data types in the background of operations. 

\
The following code is designed to cause some unexpected results in R. 

\
Make a vector named `num_char` with the following values `1`, `2`, `3`, `"a"`. 
```{r ex4_4, exercise=TRUE}


```

::: {#ex4_4-hint}
Mix numeric values (without quotes) and character values (with quotes) in the c() function.
:::

```{r ex4_4-solution}
# using = operator ----
num_char = c(1,2,3,"a")

# using <- ----
num_char <- c(1,2,3,"a")


```

```{r ex4_4-check}
grade_code(
  correct = "Great! You've created a mixed vector with both numbers and a character. Let's see what R does with this!",
  incorrect = "Mix numbers (1,2,3) and a character (\"a\") in the c() function: num_char <- c(1,2,3,\"a\")"
)
```


### Q5

What is the type of data would you expect `num_char` to be?

\
Use the `class()` function to find out the data type of `num_char`.
```{r ex4_5_setup, include=FALSE}
num_char <- c(1,2,3,"a")
```

```{r ex4_5, exercise=TRUE, exercise.setup="ex4_5_setup"}


```

::: {#ex4_5-hint}
Use the class() function with num_char as the argument.
:::

```{r ex4_5-solution}
class(num_char)
```

```{r ex4_5-check}
grade_code(
  correct = "Interesting! Even though we mixed numbers and text, R converted everything to 'character' type. This is R's way of keeping all elements the same type.",
  incorrect = "Use the class() function: class(num_char)"
)
```

What is the data type of first value in `num_char`? Use the `class()` function on the extracted value. 


First extract the first element with [1], then use class() on that: class(num_char[1])



```{r ex4_8, echo=FALSE}
)
```

### Q9

Recall that all values in a vector have the same data type, so R does work in the background to not break this rule. 

\
Now make a vector called `num_logical` with the values `1`, `2`, `3`, `TRUE`.


::: {#ex4_9-hint}
Mix numeric values and a logical value (TRUE without quotes) in the c() function.
:::

```{r ex4_9-solution}

# <- ----
num_logical <- c(1,2,3, TRUE)

```

```{r ex4_9-check}
grade_code(
  correct = "Great! You've mixed numbers with a logical value (TRUE). Let's see how R handles this combination.",
  incorrect = "Combine numbers and TRUE (without quotes): num_logical <- c(1,2,3, TRUE)"
)
```
